comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,125 @@
+name: ML-KEM
+type: kem
+principal-submitters:
+- Peter Schwabe
+auxiliary-submitters:
+- Roberto Avanzi
+- Joppe Bos
+- Léo Ducas
+- Eike Kiltz
+- Tancrède Lepoint
+- Vadim Lyubashevsky
+- John M. Schanck
+- Gregor Seiler
+- Damien Stehlé
+crypto-assumption: Module LWE+R with base ring Z[x]/(3329, x^256+1)
+website: https://pq-crystals.org/kyber/ and https://csrc.nist.gov/pubs/fips/203/ipd
+nist-round: ipd
comment.body: This (string) designation causes downstream problems where "nist-round" is supposed to be an integer. Would it make sense to assign "ipd" a special new int value (sufficiently high to be above all possible future NIST rounds but also not so high such as to permit a designation for "second public draft", etc. until finalization)? Alternatively, I'll change all logic keeping algorithms in the NIST rounds together based on integer and move it to strings.

pull_request.title: Add ML-DSA-ipd and ML-KEM-ipd & NIST supplied test vectors
pull_request.body:
Pull ML-DSA-ipd / ML-KEM-ipd from pq-crystals "standard" branch.
Adds test cases with NIST supplied test vectors: https://csrc.nist.gov/Projects/post-quantum-cryptography/post-quantum-cryptography-standardization/example-files (see also _Note on the intermediate values for ML-KEM:_ and _Note on the intermediate values for ML-DSA:_)

The NIST files are rather large (several MB) and we only use parts of the data that can be passed via the public API + randomness. So we process them and store only the data we need in `tests/PQC_Intermediate_Values` (script is included to reproduce the files)

The PR adds new test code vectors_sig.c and vectors_kem.c that for testing the NIST vectors.

The idea is to keep the current Kyber/Dilithium (round 3) versions for compatibility reasons, and add the ML-* algorithms additionally.

The naming of the algorithms is done following the IETF hackathon: ML-DSA-44-ipd, ML-DSA-65-ipd, ML-DSA-87-ipd, ML-KEM-512-ipd, ML-KEM-768-ipd, ML-KEM-1024-ipd: https://github.com/IETF-Hackathon/pqc-certificates/blob/master/docs/oid_mapping.md

TODOs:
- [x] Add NIST supplied test vectors and code to test them
- [x] Compact NIST test vectors: the files are quite large and we need only a small part of the value
- [x] Pull ML-DSA-ipd from pq-crystals "standard" branch
- [x] Pull ML-KEM-ipd from pq-crystals "standard" branch
- [x] add patches for copy_from_upstream (for renaming to ML-KEM-ipd / ML-DSA-ipd)
- [ ] ~~Pull pqclean aarch64 code (may omit for now)~~
- [x] Integrate tests with CI
- [x] Update docs
- [x] Ensure updating to latest upstream versions (e.g. with Kyberslash fixes)
- [x] Run constant-time tests on new algorithms & update valgrind files

Closes #1521.

<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [x] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,12 @@
+## License
+
+This XMSS reference implementation is Copyright (c) 2024 SandboxAQ and licensed under both the [Apache License, Version 2.0](https://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0.txt) and [MIT License](LICENSE-MIT).
+
+Unless you explicitly state otherwise, any contribution intentionally submitted for inclusion in the work by you, as defined in the Apache-2.0 license, shall be dual licensed as above, without any additional terms or conditions.
+
+This XMSS reference implementation is based on the [XMSS reference implementation written by Andreas Hülsing and Joost Rijneveld](https://github.com/XMSS/xmss-reference#license) provided under the CC0 1.0 Universal Public Domain Dedication.
+
+
+## Disclaimer
+
+The software and documentation are provided "as is" and SandboxAQ hereby disclaims all warranties, whether express, implied, statutory, or otherwise. SandboxAQ specifically disclaims, without limitation, all implied warranties of merchantability, fitness for a particular purpose, title, and non-infringement, and all warranties arising from course of dealing, usage, or trade practice. SandboxAQ makes no warranty of any kind that the software and documentation, or any products or results of the use thereof, will meet any person's requirements, operate without interruption, achieve any intended result, be compatible or work with any software, system or other services, or be secure, accurate, complete, free of harmful code, or error-free.
comment.body:
> I'm not sure either whether we can re-license CC0 to MIT unilaterally. I'll email the LF lawyers to ask them. 

After checking the original code, I'd consider that unnecessary: Even if the LF lawyers answer it'd be OK (for them), I'd consider this deeply unethical from a FOSS perspective and would thus strongly object such move: I just checked a single [sample file](https://github.com/XMSS/xmss-reference/blob/master/xmss.c) and it's 99% unchanged included in this PR (though amended).

> Otherwise we would want to go back to the authors of the original implementation to ask if they are willing to relicense under MIT. The desire to not include CC0 code here comes from past issues that have been raised (such as https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/1437) that CC) is problematic for adopters, such as Fedora.

This is also something I would find unnecessary for several reasons:
1) @ducnguyen-sb already stated "I can revert the license to CC0 (fine for us)" -- so I'd be _very_ glad about that.
2) The reference code is very old and I'm not certain it'd be possible to get hold of all authors to agree to such change of license.
3) The entity that complained about CC0 is IBM/Redhat (Fedora) -- the very same company labeling (some features of) this code [borderline irresponsible](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1650#issuecomment-1893957110) ... which I take to mean they'd not over-eagerly integrate this :) But let's check: @simo5: Can you comment on this question: Would you want to distribute this code (without setting OQS_ALLOW_XMSS_KEY_AND_SIG_GEN of course)? Would this decision change if it were CC0 or MIT licensed?

pull_request.title: Add Stateful Signature (XMSS and LMS)
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Adds implementations of stateful signatures to liboqs for XMSS and LMS. The feature include new OQS APIs to generate key-pairs, signature generation, verification, and secret key state-management. Actual secret key storage is left up to the application.

This PR also includes an enhancement to OQS SHA2 API to allow handling updates with arbitrary length buffers.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ No ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ Yes ] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)
OQS provider support is a separate and forthcoming feature. This is separated because of the need to manage the stateful of secret keys.
<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
Just a comment here, while IBM wholly owns Red Hat, we are different (and largely independent) entities, please never assume that we have unity of representation or even intent.

That said we (Red Hat) will not compile the siggen parts for sure, but CC0 has issues in general even as source code distribution, and it is not a problem just for us, it's just that we tend to be the ones that performs license due diligence early compared to other players.

In general CC0 is problematic *for software* and you should reconsider using it at all.

comment.body:
I think, but do not quote me on this because I have not asked directly, that CC0 by explicitly disclaiming any implied patent grant is a risk of submarine patent attack.

I honestly do not want to go into a debate on whether this is a problem or not, just stating what the perceived risk is which makes CC0 undesirable for code that should be free to use by all, including entities with commercial interests.

@@ -0,0 +1,12 @@
+## License
+

SandboxAQ specifically disclaims, without limitation, all implied warranties of merchantability, fitness for a particular purpose, title, and non-infringement, and all warranties arising from course of dealing, usage, or trade practice. SandboxAQ makes no warranty of any kind that the software and documentation, or any products or results of the use thereof, will meet any person's requirements, operate without interruption, achieve any intended result, be compatible or work with any software, system or other services, or be secure, accurate, complete, free of harmful code, or error-free.
comment.body:
> CC0 by explicitly disclaiming any implied patent grant is a risk of submarine patent attack.

Thanks. I now (finally, I'm slow...) get it. A more verbose statement of about the same risk:

> There is a clause in the text of the license CC0 which explicitly states that the license does not affect any patent or trademark rights that may be used in the application. The possibility of influence through patents is considered a potential threat, so licenses that do not explicitly allow the use of patents or do not waive patents are considered non-FOSS

(from https://blog.desdelinux.net/en/in-fedora-they-plan-to-stop-offering-various-spins-and-software-under-the-cc0-license/)

So I now also don't like CC0 any more. Doesn't make our problem easier given that the code in this PR (IMO) _is_ CC0.

So final question to you, @simo5 : Would you package it (without sig/gen) if we'd somehow get it (changed) to be MIT&Apache2?

+
+Unless you explicitly state otherwise, any contribution intentionally submitted for inclusion in the work by you, as defined in the Apache-2.0 license, shall be dual licensed as above, without any additional terms or conditions.
+
+This XMSS reference implementation is based on the [XMSS reference implementation written by Andreas Hülsing and Joost Rijneveld](https://github.com/XMSS/xmss-reference#license) provided under the CC0 1.0 Universal Public Domain Dedication.

comment.body: With my Red Hat fedora on: It being packaged in RHEL largely depends on industry needs. If they become widely used then we will have no choice but to ship support for XMSS and LMS.

pull_request.title: Add Stateful Signature (XMSS and LMS)
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Adds implementations of stateful signatures to liboqs for XMSS and LMS. The feature include new OQS APIs to generate key-pairs, signature generation, verification, and secret key state-management. Actual secret key storage is left up to the application.

This PR also includes an enhancement to OQS SHA2 API to allow handling updates with arbitrary length buffers.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ No ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ Yes ] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)
OQS provider support is a separate and forthcoming feature. This is separated because of the need to manage the stateful of secret keys.
<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
I can't give you a final answer at this stage because, as Hubert notes, license is just one of the factors.

We have disabled/removed unwanted (weak, broken, patent encumbered, etc...) algorithms in cryptography libraries in the past, so we'll make a determination based on multiple factors, but certainly license is one of them.
